STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
October 11, 2019
Shelly Marner
Saginaw County DHHS
P O Box 5070
411 E Genesee
Saginaw, MI 48605
RE: License #: CP730201395
Saginaw County DHHS
P O Box 5070
411 E Genesee
Saginaw, MI 48605
Dear Ms. Marner:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on September
13, 2019. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and
Modified Settlement Agreement (MSA) requirements, a written corrective action plan is
required. It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the
MSA and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MSA citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (248) 975-5053.
Sincerely,
Lonia Perry, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
(248) 860-3317
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP730201395
Licensee Name: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Address: 235 South Grand Avenue
Lansing, MI 48902
Licensee Telephone #: (517) 373-3768
Administrator/Licensee Designee: Jooyeun Chang, Designee
Name of Facility: Saginaw County DHHS
Facility Address: P O Box 5070
411 E Genesee
Saginaw, MI 48605
Facility Telephone #: (989) 758-1100
Original Issuance Date: 03/01/1991
Service Types: PLACE CHILDREN FOR ADOPTION
CERTIFY FOSTER HOMES FOR LICENSE
SUPERVISE INDEPENDENT LIVING
PLACE CHILDREN IN FOSTER HOME
EVALUATE APPLICANTS FOR ADOPTION
1

II. METHODS OF INSPECTION – A. Consultant
Date of On-site Inspection(s):08/27/2018, 08/28/2019, 09/06/2019, 09/09/2019 thru
9/11/2019 & 09/13/2019
Total No. Of Records No. of Records
Reviewed
No. of current licensed foster homes 43 6
No. of homes pending licensure 8 3
No. of Foster homes closed since the last inspection 17 5
No. of Foster homes borrowed since the last inspection 30 5
No. of Special Investigations in foster homes since last inspection 11 7

in foster care since last inspection 0 0
No. of incidents of substantiated corporal punishment in foster care
since last inspection 0 0
No. of children currently placed in licensed foster homes 48 4

since the last inspection 52 6

2

The following required records were on file and available for review:

METHODS OF INSPECTION – B. Analyst
Total No. No. Visited
No. of licensed foster homes 44 3
No. of unlicensed relatives homes 31 3
No. of independent living youth
No. of adoptive homes
Number of persons interviewed:
Foster Parents 4
Foster Children 7(2 observed)
Birth Parents 2
Independent Living Youth
Relatives 4
Adoptive Parents
Others (please identify person interviewed by role)
3

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R400.12212 Personnel records.
(3) The personnel record shall contain both of the following:
(a) A written evaluation of a staff member's performance
within a probationary period or not later than 6 months after the
staff member assumes his or her current responsibilities. After
the initial evaluation, a written evaluation shall be conducted
each year.
Three of thirteen employee records reviewed where the
employee’s position was governed by these rules, did not show
compliance:
One record showed the employee’s written probationary
evaluation due by 6/1/19 was not documented.
Two other records showed the employee’s annual evaluation
was eighteen and twenty-two days late respectively.
Repeat Violation Renewal 2018.
MCL 722.120 Investigation, inspection, and examination of conditions,
books, records, and reports; access by department, bureau
of fire services, or local authorities; records; report; forms;
confidentiality; disclosure of information; availability of
confidential records; child information cards to be provided
to department; failure of licensee to cooperate with
investigation, inspection, or examination.
(3) A licensee shall keep the records the department
prescribes regarding each child in its control and care and
shall report to the department, when requested, the facts
the department requires with reference to the children upon
forms furnished by the department. Except as otherwise
provided in this subsection and subsection (4), records
regarding children and facts compiled about children and
their parents and relatives are confidential and disclosure
of this information shall be properly safeguarded by the
childcare organization, the department, and any other entity
in possession of the information.
4

One of seven special investigation records reviewed showed
documentation of children protective service involvement in the
special evaluation; utilization of language such as CPS was
indicated.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2018
R400.1234 Reevaluation.
(8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and shall make a
licensing recommendation to the department at least 15
calendar days before the expiration date of the foster home
license.
One of six open foster home records reviewed showed the
licensing recommendation was not submitted to the department
at least 15 days before the respective foster home’s 8/15/19
licensing expiration date.
Repeat Violation-Renewal 2018.
R400.1237 Special evaluation.
(1) An agency shall do all of the following when anyone in the
agency receives information that relates to possible
noncompliance with any foster home rule:
(a) Submit a special investigation record to the department's
licensing authority within 5 working days in the manner
prescribed by the department.
One of seven special evaluation records reviewed did not show
documentation of submission of a special investigation record to
the licensing authority within 5 working days.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2018. Renewal 2016.
R400.12327 Special evaluation
(1) An agency shall do all of the following when anyone in the
agency receives information that relates to possible
noncompliance with any foster home rule:
(c) Conduct a thorough investigation including all necessary
collateral contacts.
One of seven special evaluations reviewed did not show
documentation that all persons named in the complaint were
interviewed. Nor that a reported police contact was examined.
5

R400.12327 Special evaluation.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report that includes all of the
following information:
(d) Dates and places of contacts, names of persons interviewed,
and names of the interviewers. If children are interviewed, their
last names shall not be included in the report.
One of seven special evaluations reviewed had two children’s
first and last name within the report.
400.12328 Foster home record.
2) The record shall contain all of the following information:
(d) a placement list of all children placed in the foster home,
including all of the following information about each child:
(iii) Date of, and reasons for, a child’s removal from the foster
home.
In four of five closed foster home records reviewed the
placement list did not document the date each child was
removal and the reason for the removal.
Repeat Violation-Renewal 2018.
R400.12404 Placement.
(7) An agency shall document, in the child’s record, within 7
calendar days after placement, the information specified in
R400.12417(1) and all of the following information:
(g) Documentation of the child’s placement preparation.
Two of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show
documentation of the child’s preparation for placement.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2018.
R400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the child's
record before a change of placement occurs:
(e) Replacement preparation, regardless of the child's age,
appropriate to the child's capacity to understand, which includes
an explanation to all relevant parties as to why the change is
necessary.
6

One of six closed foster child records reviewed did not show
documentation of the child’s preparation for the change.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2018.
R400.12405 Change of placement.
(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the child in a
foster home, then both of the following shall be documented
before a change in placement.
(a) A summary of service provided during care up to the time of
the change in placement and the need that remain to be met
(b) Provision for any continuing services.
One of six closed foster child records reviewed did not show
documentation of the child’s needs that remain to be met and
provision for any continuing services
Repeat Violation-Renewal 2018.
R400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows, unless a
greater frequency is medically indicated:
(ii) For a child 2 years of age or older, a physical examination
shall have been completed within 12 months before placement
or a new physical examination shall be completed within 30
calendar days after placement.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed showed the
child’s date of placement as 1/18/19; and the medical due by
2/17/19 was not documented.
R400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the
following information before the placement or replacement of a
child.
(c) Available known information about the child’s health.
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the child.
(e) All known emotional and psychological factors relating to the
care of the child.
(f) All known behaviors of the child.
(g) Circumstances necessitating placement or replacement of
the child.
7

(h) Any other known information to enable the foster parent to
provide a stable, safe, and healthy environment for the foster
child and the foster family, including information about siblings
who do not reside in the foster home.
Three of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show
documentation of compliance:
 Three records did not show documentation of (c), (d), (f)
(g) and (h).
 One record did not show documentation of (e).
Repeat Violation-Renewal 2018.
R400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
One of twenty-three updated service plans (USP) reviewed was
forty-seven days late.
Repeat Violation-Renewal 2018.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility
is in compliance will all additional ISEP requirements except for the following:
ISEP 4.22 ISEP 4.22 MiSACWIS (Commitment 22).
DHHS will maintain an operational statewide automated child
welfare information system (“MiSACWIS”) which will be the
primary tracking system and satisfy federal reporting
requirements.
In two of six open foster home records; five of five closed foster
home records, and one of four enrolled applicant records
reviewed, various records did not show consistent
documentation of uploads of all forms, (i.e. application, signed
3130A, social work contacts, 3706, closing summaries,
placement list, signed special evaluation, open & closed 259) to
the system.
8

In five of eight open foster child records and four of six closed
foster child records reviewed, various records did not show that
all signed service plans, parent agency treatment plan
agreements, FTM DHS-1105, were consistently uploaded to
MISACWIS.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2018.
ISEP 6.16 Relative Foster Parents (Commitment 52).
(a) When placing a child with a relative who has not been
previously licensed as a foster parent, DHHS shall:
(3) within 30 days, complete a home study determining whether
the relative should, upon completion of training and submission
of any other required documents, be licensed as a foster parent.
One of four unlicensed relative applicant records reviewed,
where this rule was applicable, showed a home study(3130A)
was completed more than 30 days after the child’s 8/21/18
placement.
Repeat Violation-Renewal 2018.
ISEP 6.33 Assessments and Service Plans Content (Commitment 69).
(c) Service plans shall be signed by the caseworker, the
caseworker’s supervisor, the parent(s), and the child(ren), if of
age to participate. If the parent(s) or child(ren) or both are not
available or decline to sign the plan, the service plan shall
include an explanation of the steps taken to involve them and
shall identify any follow-up actions to be taken to secure their
participation in services.
Three of twenty-eight service plans reviewed did not show
documentation of the birth parent’s signature.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2018, Interim 2017, Renewal
2016.
ISEP 6.49 Medical Passports (Commitment 85).
(a) At the time the child is placed or re-placed, the foster
care provider shall receive the child’s Medical Passport,
which must contain the information required by MCL
722.954c(2) and DHHS Policy FOM 801 (dated 3-1-2015) (or
any successor policies approved by the Monitors). And at
least quarterly thereafter, and updated Medical Passport
must be prepared, as required by the “Medical Passports”
section of DHHS Policy FOM 801 (dated 3-1-2015) (or any
9

successor policy approved by the Monitors) and provided
to the foster care provider.
Four of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show
documentation that the medical passport was provided the
caregiver.
Three of the four did not show documentation the medical
passport was updated quarterly.
A fourth record related to a caregiver reporting to the DCWL
Analyst they were not familiar with the medical passport. The
MISACWIS record documented the child’s placement as 1/5/19
and the medical passport was provided on 6/19/19. Additionally,
it showed the caregiver signed a medical passport on 8/1/19.
Repeat Violations- Renewal 2018, Interim 2017, Renewal
2016.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
Policy FOM 722- Family Team Meetings.
6B
FTMs should include child welfare staff, parents, caretakers,
foster parents, children, youth, and may also include extended
family, friends, neighbors, community-based service providers,
community representatives, tribal representatives, for Indian
children, or other professionals involved with the family.
Each meeting must be documented in MiSACWIS using the
FTM hyperlink and all of the appropriate forms must be
completed for each type of meeting
Certain circumstances, events, and/or stages of case
progression mandate FTMs must occur within the required time
frames as outlined in the following tables…
Two of twenty-eight services plans reviewed did not show
compliance:
 One did not show documentation of an FTM for a 7/5/18-
10/4/18 USP.
10

 A second did not show documentation of a DHS-1105
form for a 9/19/18-12/17/18 USP.
In a third child’s record where the caregiver reported to the
Division of Child Welfare Licensing (DCWL) Analyst she was not
invited to family team meetings. The record did not show
documentation the caregiver was invited to or participated in the
recorded family team meetings or signed the DHS-1105 forms
of the meeting.
Policy FOM 722- Foster Care- Initial Service Plan.
8
Case service plan approval process requires the foster care
supervisor to:
 Review and approve the ISP within 14 calendar days of
the Report Date
One of five initial service plans reviewed showed the child’s
2/8/19-3/6/19 ISP approval was two days late on 3/22/19.
Policy FOM 722- Foster Care-Parent Agency Treatment Plan & Service
8C Agreement.
Signature: When completed, obtain all signatures as
appropriate, including those of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care
worker, supervisor, foster parent, caregiver, any youth age 14
and older and in the case of placement agency foster care
cases, the local DHS office designee
Of twenty-eight service plans reviewed, seven did not contain
the foster parent/caregiver’s signature.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2018, Interim 2017, Renewal 2016.
Policy FOM 722- Foster Care- Updated Service Plan.
9
Case service plan approval process requires the foster care
supervisor to:
 Review and approve the USP within 14 calendar days of
the Report Date
One of twenty-three updated service plans reviewed showed the
child’s 9/19/18-12/17/18 USP approval was three days late on
1/3/19.
11

Policy FOM 722- Foster Care Action Summary
09C
The Foster Care/Juvenile Justice (FC/JJ) Action Summary,
DHS-69 (RFF 69), is used whenever there is “action” on a case.
The foster care action summary is generated from SWSS FAJ.
The DHS worker must complete the DHS-69, Action Summary
(RFF 69) in SWSS. Child placing agencies will continue to use
the DHS-69, Action Summary template. This form also serves
as notice to the courts of changes in placements, parent's living
situation and the FC worker/agency, as identifying information is
indicated. The FC/JJ action summary meets licensing
requirements for replacement documentation (See FOM 722-
03) and in most cases, agency transfer and case closing
summary (see below). The FC/JJ action summary must also be
used for foster care transfer to adoption.
Which Cases/ When What does this mean
All foster care cases where there is:
1. A replacement.
2. Termination from foster care placement.
Two of eight open foster child records reviewed did not show
documentation of a DHS-69 for the child’s replacement on
11/28/18 and 5/7/19 respectively.
Three of six closed foster child records reviewed did not show
documentation of a DHS-69 for the child’s return home/case
closure.
2. is a Repeat Violation- Renewal 2018.
Policy FOM 722- Case Closure Discharge Document.
15
The caseworker must provide a copy of educational documents
social security card, birth certificate, and completed medical
passport to the birth parent or guardian at the time of case
closure.
Three of six closed foster child records reviewed, where the
child was returned to a parent or guardian did not show
documentation all the items identified in the standard were
provided to the birth parent or guardian.
Repeat Violation- Renewal 2018.
12

CI-16-182a Communication Issuance
Security Awareness Training for Fingerprint Base Criminal
History Requirements
Security Awareness Training (SAT) is required for authorized
personnel who have been granted access to fingerprint-based
Criminal History Record Information (CHRI). This training
provides information on what fingerprint based CHRI is, who
has access, how to ensure this information remains secure both
physically an electronically, and how you can use this
information appropriately.
All non-contracted and governmental CPA employees,
subcontractors, subcontractor’s employees or volunteers who
are authorized to have access to fingerprint based CHRI must
successfully complete SAT within six months of appointment to
a position with CHRI access and every two years thereafter.
Eight of nine current employees listed as having access to CHRI
did not show documentation the employee completed the
required recertification training timely:
 One staff’s two-year recertification training was due by
1/25/19 and completed over two months late on 4/11/19.
 A second staff’s two-year recertification training was due
by 1/20/19 and completed over six months late on 8/2/19.
 A third staff’s two-year recertification training was due by
1/11/19 and completed over six months late on 7/31/19.
 A fourth staff’s two-year recertification training was due
by 2/1/19 and completed six months late on 8/1/19.
 A fifth staff’s two-year recertification training was due by
12/20/19 and completed in August 2019 over seven
months late.
 Three other staff’s certifications were not documented.
CI-17-124 Communication Issuance.
Foster Care 13:1 Caseload Monitoring
Beginning January 2017, the department set forth direction that
supported local MDHHS and private agency partners working
on individualized county plans to reduce caseload ratios.
The requirement for foster care to meet 13:1 caseload ratio is
effective October 1, 2017 for all public and private foster care
workers.
Two of four foster care workers had caseloads of fifteen.
13

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas
R400.12326(1) (c) &(d)Borrowed Home
 The agency was apprised it shall clearly indicate the name of the person
endorsing the evaluation and reevaluation, along with the date of that
endorsement.
R400.12327(5)(e) Special evaluation
 The agency was apprised it shall consistently and clearly document the worker’s
analysis/summation as to how the worker arrived at conclusions of compliance or
noncompliance as based on finding of facts in the special evaluation.
Policy FOM 722- 6H Documentation of Contacts.
 The agency is apprised to ensure all face-to-face contacts are listed in the
service plan.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
 None this inspection.
14

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
This corrective action plan related to the agency’s 2018 Renewal Inspection, where
the agency received twenty-three rule citations, one ACT 116 citation, five ISEP
citations and five policy citations. The agency was not completely successful with the
correction action plan, but there was a reduction in the number of rule and ISEP
citations this inspection.
DCWL ANALYST ISSUES ADDRESSED:
Safety and Concern Alert #1,
Concern:
Foster parent reported she is not involved in the development of the case
treatment/service plan.
Resolution:
The agency reported there was no documentation that the foster parent was involved in
development of the treatment plan. MISACWIS showed the foster parent did not sign
the PATPA for the ISP(2/8/19-3-6/19) but signed the 3/7/19-6/4/19 service plan on
6/21/19. The agency received a citation under policy, 722-8C related to the Parent
agency treatment plan agreement .
Concern:
Agency not forthcoming about the child’s behavior issues.
Resolution:
The agency reported at the time of the child’s 2/8/19 placement this 1 ½ year old child
did not display behavioral issues. MISACWIS confirmed the child’s age and date of
placement, but not information provided the foster parent about the child at placement.
The agency received a citation under R400.12417 for Foster parent information.
Concern:
Not informed of FTM’s
Resolution:
15

The MISACWIS record did not show documentation of the foster parent’s invitation or
participation in FTMs for the child. The agency received a citation under policy 722-6B
for Family team meetings.
Safety and Concern Alert #2
Concern:
No safety and concerns indicated.
Safety and Concern Alert #3
Concern:
The agency doesn’t provide known information about the foster children. Most of the
time they give information but there are times when they aren’t honest at all.
Resolution:
The alert did not name a child this concern related to. The agency reviewed prior child
placements for the foster parent and did not locate documentation of information
provided the foster parent at those placements. The agency received a prior citation
under R400.12417 for Foster parent information.
Safety and Concern Alert # 4
No safety and concerns indicated.
Safety and Concern Alert #5
No safety and concerns indicated.
Safety and Concern Alert #6
Concern:
The unlicensed relatives have their 6-month old niece in their care. The caregivers do
not have an insurance card/number for the minor child. When asked about the infant
receiving routine medical care, the relative stated the doctor’s office have to call and
check for the infant’s current insurance status.
Resolution:
MISACWIS showed the child was ten days old at the time of her 1/5/19 relative
placement. The agency reported the relative was given an emergency medical
authorization at placement, as documented in MISACWIS. The worker verified on
6/19/19 the caregiver had the child’s emergency medical authorization and ID numbers.
The Medicaid card was reordered and will be provided to the caregiver once received.
Concern:
The home isn’t equipped with a working carbon monoxide detector.
Resolution:
The agency ensured that family purchased a carbon monoxide detector on 6/19/19. A
photo of the detector in place is on file.
16

Concern:
The agency gave them videos to watch, so they can start the licensing process.
Resolution:
The agency reported it had given the family the video as a starting point. It continued to
reach out to the relative for licensure. MISACWIS confirmed the latter; showed the
relative reported not wanting to move forward with licensing, having difficulty attending
required training; were trying to pursue guardianship of the child. The agency is
continuing efforts with the relative.
Concern:
Currently they are using a bassinet for the infant.
Resolution:
The agency assisted the relative in securing a baby bed on 6/26/19. A photo of the
baby bed is on file.
Concern:
Not familiar with the medical passport.
Resolution:
MISACWIS showed the child was placed with the caregiver 1/5/19; the worker provided
the caregiver a medical passport for the child on 6/19/19. The caregiver signed a
medical passport 8/1/19. The agency received a citation under ISEP 6.49 for Medical
passport.
RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue on a
regular license.
October 3, 2019
________________________________________
Lonia Perry Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
October 11, 2019
________________________________________
Linda D. Tansil Date
17

Area Manager
18
